151160037.review:
Preparación de la tortilla de patatas
Pelamos las patatas, las lavamos para quitar restos de suciedad y muy importante, las secamos. Cortamos en láminas semifinas, a mí no me gusta que se deshagan sino que al freírlas se tuesten un poco. Las colocamos en un bol grande, donde luego vamos a mezclar con el huevo y añadimos sal al gusto. Removemos bien y reservamos.
Elegimos nuestra sartén más grande y antiadherente. La ponemos al fuego y añadimos un buen aceite de oliva virgen extra. No tengáis miedo en gastaros un poco de dinero en aceite, le va a dar ese punto de sabor que distingue vuestra tortilla de las demás, podéis emplear muchas variedades: arbequina, picual, cornicabra, hojiblanca, royal… el que más os guste, pero de calidad.
Introducimos las patatas cortadas y ya saladas y dejamos que se cocinen durante aproximadamente de veinte a treinta minutos a fuego bajo. El tema del grosor de las patatas también va a gustos. Hay quien prefiere cortarlas a trozos muy pequeños, en láminas muy finas que casi se rompan al freír o más bien grandes.
Mientras se están friendo las patatas, en el bol donde luego vamos a echar las patatas batimos los huevos, reservamos. Pelamos la cebolla y cortamos lo más fino posible.
En otra sartén calentamos aceite de oliva y añadimos los trozos de cebolla. Pochamos hasta que tenga un color dorado, que tenga un punto de caramelización pero sin llegar a quemarse. La cebolla se hará antes que las patatas, así que escurrimos y añadimos al bol con el huevo batido. Quitamos con una espumadera de la sartén, dejando las patatas con el menor resto de aceite posible, bien escurridas. Si no queremos nada de aceite extra podemos emplear un colador grande. Las dejamos escurrir y luego las introducimos al bol con la cebolla y el huevo.

151086449.review: I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 13 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

151080718.review: De los Vampire Survivors-like (dale, convengamos de una vez en llamarlos Bullet Heaven y zanjada la cuestión) es uno de los más originales, y el más dinámico. Las partidas son cortas, y están divididas en 20 olas con un final boss, y al final de cada ola podemos comprar items con la moneda acumulada. Los gráficos pueden no parecer los más lindos al principio pero uno le va tomando cariño. El movimiento es ágil y la jugabilidad frenética. Tiene más de 30 personajes para desbloquear, todos con características muy diferentes entre sí que cambian la manera en la que uno planea las run: elegir diferentes items o priorizar distintas stats. Tiene mucha rejugabilidad con 5 niveles de dificultad para cada personaje, y muchos items desbloqueables. Ojalá sigan agregándole contenido, porque es un juego que engancha muy fácil y es ideal para rellenar esos ratitos libres que uno tiene a veces.

150983057.review:
A Spudtacular Protagonist

At the heart of Brotato is the titular Brotato, a potato with a knack for wielding multiple weapons simultaneously. This unique ability allows for a wide variety of playstyles, from close-quarters combat to long-range pew-pewing.

Addictive Gameplay

Brotato's gameplay is deceptively simple yet incredibly addictive. Players must navigate an arena filled with enemies, blasting them away with a variety of weapons. The pace is fast and frenetic, and the waves of enemies never seem to end, making for a truly exhilarating experience.

Endless Replayability

Brotato's roguelike nature ensures that no two runs are the same. With a massive arsenal of weapons, perks, and items to unlock, there's always something new to discover. And the game's difficulty can be adjusted to suit players of all skill levels.

Charming Aesthetics

Brotato's pixelated graphics and quirky humor add to its charm. The game's world is full of endearing characters and hilarious animations.

A Spud-tacular Sound Design

Brotato's sound design is equally impressive. The sound effects are satisfyingly crunchy, and the music is catchy and upbeat.

Overall, Brotato is a must-play for any fan of roguelikes. With its addictive gameplay, endless replayability, and charming aesthetics, Brotato is sure to have you spudding out for more.

150976867.review:
[h1]"Fast-Paced Fun with Impressive Variety - A Brotato Review"[/h1]

If you're looking for a game that's easy to dive into for a quick burst of fun but equally simple to put down, "Brotato" is a perfect choice. This isn't just another shooter game; it's a compact package of exhilaration that keeps calling you back for more. Here's why I highly recommend it:

Perfect for Quick Sessions: One of the best things about "Brotato" is how it fits into any schedule. Whether you have a few minutes to spare or an hour, this game provides an immediately satisfying experience without the need for long-term commitment. Jump in, blast some aliens, and step out whenever you need to - it's as simple as that.

Diverse Character Roster: The variety of characters in "Brotato" is truly impressive. Each character brings its own unique playstyle, making the gameplay feel fresh and exciting every time. This diversity ensures that players can continually experiment and find new ways to enjoy the game, catering to all types of gamers.

Endless Build Possibilities: "Brotato" truly shines in its build variety. The joy of experimenting with different builds, tweaking your strategy, and seeing the results is a core part of the game's appeal. It's thrilling to mix and match abilities and weapons to create the perfect alien-fighting machine.

Simple Yet Clever Design: Developed using the Godot Engine, "Brotato" stands out with its straightforward yet ingenious design. It's a testament to how a game doesn't need complex graphics to be engaging. The simplicity of the design paired with smart gameplay mechanics makes "Brotato" a standout indie game.

In conclusion, "Brotato" is a gem of a game that's easy to pick up but hard to put down. Its blend of simplicity, variety, and replayability makes it a must-try for anyone who enjoys a good shooter with a twist. Definitely, a game worth adding to your collection!

150794024.review:
It's good, it's fun
Here are some tips and tricks for you if you want to try:
-Character Choice: Try a ranged character like the ranger for effective gameplay.
-Beta Branch: Play on the beta branch under Steam preferences, as the boss is easier and less buggy there.
-Defense Strategy: Focus on acquiring a lot of defenses like HP, Armor, and Healing, allowing room for mistakes.
-Shopping Strategy: Avoid buying small gains unless they're cheap. Stick to your plan, and prioritize rare weapons for better value and power increase.
-Luck Factor: Focus on Luck early in the game. Luck in the initial turns (1-5) will significantly strengthen your run. Continue focusing on luck until about floor 10, then switch to concentrating on weapons and defense.
-Weapon Choice: Lifesteal works well with very fast weapons like SMG, Minigun, and Flamethrower. It's also effective, albeit to a lesser extent, with AOE weapons.
-Item Availability: The items you hold will appear more frequently in the store. For example, holding a wrench will result in more wrenches appearing in the store.
-Stat Prioritization: Some stats to be wary of are:
Range: It slows down melee weapon attack speed, and ranged weapons already have sufficient range.
Harvesting: Generally not worth it, except possibly very early in the game.
Engineering: Avoid dabbling in this unless you're fully committed.
Elemental: Extremely strong if fully committed, but avoid getting distracted from your main build and survival strategy

150771470.review:
This game is like the cute and cuddly younger sibling to Vampire Survivor, meaning he appears to be a darling little angel until mom and dad aren't looking, and then you want to throw him through the drywall because of how infuriating and obnoxious he is. Yet, like any younger sibling, you only you get to hate on him, and will defend him from anyone who tries to pick on him.

I have a love/hate relationship with Brotato. On the one hand, the art style, gameplay, and easy to understand game mechanics lure you into the sense that this game will lead to a chill play sesh (+1 if you are using the Steamdeck, which it feels perfect on). On the other hand, unlike Vampire Survivor you are constrained to an arena, which makes the increasingly difficult mobs even harder to manage, and it truely feels like a bullet hell. What I like about this game over Vampire Survivor is the emphasis on creating a build using in game currency to buy items and weapons that alter stats. You may increase your damage, but now you have no armor and your speed is reduced to nothing. Every purchase is a decision that can bite you in the ass later.

Also, if you have trouble beating levels, you can adjust enemy health, speed, and damage in accessibility settings. There is no shame in it, and getting all of the unlocks is more fun than repeatedly dying over and over again, which you will do. 

10/10

150677841.review:
I initially struggled to connect with games in the "Vampire Survivors" sub-genre, finding them mildly entertaining for about half an hour. However, Brotato managed to capture my interest more than any other game of this style. The game's unique twist, placing players in the shoes of a potato, turned out to be surprisingly engaging. The potato comes in various forms, and unlocking different characters with their own traits added a layer of depth, making each playthrough feel distinct.

I appreciated the game's adjustable difficulty, accommodating both seasoned players and newcomers. Throughout the gameplay, the progression system allowed for character enhancement and weapon upgrades, leading to a sense of accomplishment and eventual victory. Brotato proved to be a well-thought-out rogue-lite, offering a fun and casual way to pass the time without being overly complicated.

The combat mechanics were a standout feature, providing a satisfying experience with precise hit-boxes and diverse combat styles. The consistent and visually appealing art style, along with excellent sound design, contributed to an overall polished feel. The extensive variety of weapons, items, and characters demonstrated a careful balance, ensuring that each choice mattered during gameplay.

While the game had its drawbacks, such as overly easy achievements and occasional glitches, the positives outweighed the negatives. The affordability, replayability, and short run times made it a game I'd recommend, especially for those with a busy schedule. It's clear that not every game is for everyone, but Brotato managed to exceed my expectations and offered a unique and enjoyable gaming experience.

150654478.review: This is one of the best games in the "wave survivor" genre. The amount of characters, items and mechanics not only allow for diverse gameplay, but requires it. In Vampire Survivors, after unlocking most of the characters, I felt like I was going for the same build in every run, independent of the character and map I was playing. In Brotato that is not possible: most characters have their own restrictive weaknesses and strengths, making some builds inviable for them in exchange for making other builds exclusive.  It is quite unique.

150645385.review: Don't think of it as a SHMUP or a Vampire Survivors clone - it's actually the perfect distillation of an aRPG with stat choices, equipment choices, and meaningful decisions made throughout. And unlike most aRPGs which drown you in stats but rarely give you meaningful information about the decisions you make, Brotato gives the perfect amount of detail to help you learn. I never knew I needed to know how many kills each weapon had until a game told me, and now I wish every game had it. Would be a bargain at five times the price, don't hesitate, buy it now.

I nominated this game for a Steam award so I am now leaving this review here to say I voted.



Solid Game though as well, the game came out in early access around the time the whole Vampire Survivors craze occurred. While most games like this being released at that time were carbon copies of Vampire Survivors, this game managed to use the same formula while changing it up by having multiple waves instead of just a continuous run and a shop in between waves to buy items from. All and all a great game especially for the low asking price and if you like games like this you should buy it.

150571246.review: Brotato is a delightful top-down arena shooter roguelite that offers a unique and entertaining experience. Controlling a potato armed with up to 6 weapons adds a charming twist to the gameplay. The diverse traits and items allow for the creation of exciting and varied builds, ensuring each playthrough feels fresh. The vibrant visuals, creative enemy design, and adrenaline-pumping soundtrack contribute to the game's overall appeal. With its perfect blend of challenge and fun, Brotato is a must-play for fans of the genre.
